I love the Hitman Series and this is a great Base Game. But i bought it because of the VR Support on Steam and damm. The VR is terrible. I dont have a Problem with Motion Sickness in Games like Boneworks or Half Life Alyx and i prefer the Walking setting but in Hitman 3 its Terrible. I got so nauseous after only 30 min i had to stop playing. Its super Disoriented just doing Normal things and its Super Buggy. If you want to get the base Game and dont have a VR Headset or you dont want to try it, get Hitman 3. Its a Great Game and its looks beutiful. If you want Hitman 3 for the VR Mode, dont. Its not ready and its kind a sad. I have a really good Gaming PC and it still Lagged like Hell.

I was awaken by the sound of the tower defenses powering on and the air sirens warning of impending attack. I jumped out of bed running put my armor on and grabbed my guns. I made my way out onto the tower and saw Zavala standing like the pillar of strength he is staring off toward the traveler.  Zavala looked like a majestic Greek god in all of his muscle bound glory.As I ran out of the hanger and up to Zavala I slapped his ass open palmed. With a stern look in his eyes he shouted."Guardian not here" then he winked and stuck out his tongue at me. "I need you to go to the moon"I turned away looking at the ground and unable to look at him and he walked up behind me and hugged me from the back I never felt so safe in his strong embrace. I could feel his lips tickling the bottom of my my ear "please for me guardian"I tried to push him away almost in tears but his embrace was so strong. "Please..."I shook my head "no""Come on guardian do it for daddy Zala"He knew that would melt my frozen heart. I turned around leaned in for a big strong rock hard throbbing man on man hug and the smell of his pungent man musk filled my nostrils. As I turned to go back to the hanger Zavala shouted "GUARDIAN"I stopped and turned and he walked up to me and held out his hand I extended mine and he embraced cupping my hand between his soft hands pulling my hand up to his mouth extending my fingers putting them in his mouth and slowly pulling them in and out a few times moaning  "just one more taste before you leave" I could feel my knees shaking should I tell him "Zavala I lov" He quickly put his thicc man finger right across my lips I could tell I was blushing."Not now Guardian" as a single tear ran down his face. I leaned in and licked the tear off his face"I am kissing your tears away so you can be strong for the tower Zavala""Gardian if you can be strong for me I can be strong for you" he smirked "Guardian we can't send you off into battle with your armor not properly attached"I felt his hand on my thigh armor making it's way toward my center. He grabbed the tip of my zipper and slowly pulled it up making constant eye contact. Then he gave me a quick pat. "Wouldn't want anything getting damaged"I could hear Lord Shaxx in the background "Gaaaaaaaay"Zavala slowly turned to look back at the traveler. "Make haste guardian the moon needs you"Drifter caught up to me I could see the hurt in his eyes. I wished with everything in me he wouldn't say anything.I could feel his hurt it was the same hurt I once felt."Let's be bad guys in gambit"It was over and he knew it.I walked back toward Holliday in the hanger "Where to guardian""The moon""Why the moon?""The moon's haunted" I pulled out my phallic shotgun a symbol of my stunted manhood and licked it. I pumped the rack loading a hot load into the chamber and it prematurely went off. Amanda screamed."Ah! Watch it"I was real embarrassed "that uh... that's never happened to me before"The screen fades to blackOpening cinematics to Destiny 2 Shadowkeep10/10 gameplay would recommend.

Bought the game on a whim, based on a few people I know enjoying it. Didn't know much about it before I started playing. At the point of writing this, I have completed the main storyline, passed the cauldron in the expansion area storyline (The Cut), and also completed probably 75%+ of the collectibles (though I can't see me finishing them off).Thoroughly enjoyed the main storyline, which details how the current 'world' came about.Things which I think could be improved:* Climbing routes are denoted with white/yellow markings (semi-puzzles in some cases, especially the expansion area), sometimes these weren't really visible. They should be highlighted with the focus, this would remove the annoyance when feeling stuck half way through a route (and then needing to fall off, to get a better view).* When walking past NPCs in populated areas, you will hear them say phrases. There seems to be about 5-10 phrases on loop, regardless of where you are. So after a while it just becomes annoying to hear the same things over and over.* Deathbringer is an awful machine to fight, it will often end up super high in the air directly above you. Where you can't aim anywhere close to vertically up, I'm not sure what the trick for killing it is supposed to be.* You can cheese many of the large machine fights, by taking advantage of the fact all machines (except mounts) are tied to a certain area. So you can often stand slightly outside of their area behind an obstacle and tackle them whilst taking minimal damage. This is a bit harder with some of the largest machines, which can destroy large parts of the environment, but still possible.* Controlling mounts always felt a bit janky so I generally preferred to travel on foot. Also, trying to pick up plants whilst on mount often ended up in being mistimed, and me jumping off the mount.* When dying/loading save, my equipped weapon/arrow would always return to hunting arrows, rather than hard point/whatever I was previously using. Tedious.* Blast wire seems a bit OP,  really easy to kill some of the machines with it (Frostclaws probably being the worst offender in this case)* The expansion area (The Cut) introduces some new mechanics (snow storms when you're outside making visiblity awful, more puzzle-esque climbing route, 'cursed machines'). In general, I think these could have all done with a bit more QA, they don't feel as smooth and player friendly as the main game's content.Don't let this criticism take away from the positive review though, the main storyline is thoroughly worth playing.  The post credits scene, suggests there might be a sequel following Syler, I'd like to see that.

Fun game with a large group of friends (e.g. 6+), but the incentives need changing to improve public players. Has a few rough edges, but well worth the low price if you have people to play with.Currently many players joining public matches instantly leave games whereby they don't end up imposter. This can leave games balanced for 10 players, with as few as 5 players (2 imposter, 3 crew) straight after the game has started. At this point, only one crew needs to die for the imposters to have won. Rendering the game pointless. A solution to this could be giving players a 5-10 minute timeout from public games, if they leave a game before they have been killed/ejected (though this could also backfire with players afk in cafe at start).There are harder to solve problems with public games, whereby players will out themselves as the imposter. This somewhat renders them a problem now, as if they aren't playing a long con, you can be sure they are never the imposter. I'm less sure how to remedy this, other than not playing public games (or replacing find server with matchmaking and player rankings etc, but that adds a whole host of complexity).In terms of gameplay, there are a wide range of settings which can be modified in hosted games. These can vastly unbalance the gameplay when abused (e.g. harming crew, improving imposters).My primary complaint however, would be that when an imposter you can't click vents to enter them. You instead have to click the vent button. This regularly catches me out, making me slower to enter vents. Consistency of clicking things to do tasks across the board would be useful.Oh and the swipe card task can be annoying until you learn the appropriate swipe speed.

Poor storyline (to be expected with Just Cause games, that's not really why you play them), made 100x worse by loads of cutscenes, all of which are unskippable. Several missions consist of nothing but a 10 minute cutscene which unlocks a different mission on the otherside of the map. The final mission of the main storyline, you probably spend longer in cutscenes than you do actually completing objectives.Otherwise, game has much the same usual just cause gameplay (essentially invulnerable, fly around with a grapple destroying things and killing enemies, the missions are very forgiving in this regard, if you do die you only restart the current checkpoint or less). However, instead of capturing individual bases, you now complete a mission which enables you to 'move troops' into a region. You're supposed to unlock spare troops by earning chaos points, but it appears to be broken, because i kept gaining troops by unlocking regions. Ended the game with 19 spare troops and all regions unlocked, about 5 levels below max chaos. They should have kept it simple like the previous games, destroy a base, it turns blue.The expansion pack content is pretty eh, the demon/alien one really doesn't fit the game (I also uncovered a bug, where if i entered the demon dome in a helicopter, completion of the objectives didn't move the mission on until i died which reset them. The underground car battles one just wasn't my thing (drive a car that has built on guns around a track and get a high enough score to proceed). The agency one is actually kind of fun, as it introduces some novel content (enemies with grapples, new weapons/vehicles).The game also has way too many collectible tasks to complete to earn all the unlocks, something like 150 speed challenges, 150 pass this vehicle through this ring, 150 wingsuit challenges (pass through 2-4 rings). Most are easy to complete with a couple of attempts, a few make no obvious sense. Then there are about 15 each, elite ring and vehicle challenges, most of which are ridiculous and require you trying to get a boat inland and other stupid things. At the time of writing the review, I think i've got about 50% of all the none elite tasks, and im way too fatigued to finish.
Really fun, just watch out for any furniture near your play space.The safe mode kinda helps with this.
Make sure to play the free demo level first, doesn't feel significantly different from the previous Hitman game.

Refreshingly novel concept for a puzzle game. Simple enough gameplay that it can be casually approached without explanation.Took me around 30 minutes to reach level 12 where I first got stuck. So I expect the total playtime will come in around 2-3 hours, reasonable considering the cost. (I'll try to remember to update the review when I get that far).Cons:* The alternate zoom out camera is a bit arkward to control* Minor graphical artifacts (dark pixels that flicker for a second or two), some of these seem to appear at the seams between blocks, the cause of other less frequent artiefacts is unclear.

This game has combat near identical to the batman games, with the addition of some car-car combat, presumably a consequence of the same publisher/game engine.It plays similarly to batman/far cry/just cause, whereby you roam an open world completing templated tasks (clearing camps/landmines, removing scarecrows/snipers scavenging collectibles and capturing trophies from convoys). With an additional storyline providing missions which unlock extra areas of the map and a few car upgrades.These activities net you scrap and some form of points, which you can use to upgrade your vehicle/equipment and bonuses respectively, whilst also reducing 'threat' in the area which should mean less enemies are roaming (this is implied by the game, but not 1sure if it's as effective as suggested). Game has some minor issues:* I've had enemies despawn for no visible reason during combat.* 20 hours into the game, having cleared Jeet's whole territory and most of Gutgash. I've only needed to jump twice. They keybinding is left ctrl, but this is not introduced anywhere during the game, so by the time you reach the need 15 hours in you probably assume there is no jump. However it's been necessary to access one hot air balloon and one loot (in a train carriage in the eastern tunnels). I googled the prior and found a steam community thread discussing it.* Default volume settings, car engine sounds are way too loud for my taste relative to voices. I haven't attempted to change this in settings yet, I just adjust my physical volume knob for speakers regularly.* Until you do enough story to get the explosive car weapon, some activities  seem a little off limits.* Usual issue whereby I suck at combat when I'm swarmed by 15 enemies and can't keep them all on screen at once, 5+ of which have special abilities. There's probably some strategy for this that I'm missing.General verdict is that if you like open world games with templated tasks you will probably enjoy this, otherwise you won't.I bought it in a sale for 75% off and it seems well worth it given the time I've spent playing it thus far.

Compelling story, and attractive art style in both terms of graphics and soundtrack. Lots of chances for screenshots. Took me around 2.5 hrs to complete.Not sure whether I will bother to give it a further play through now I've completed the storyline (to finish the achievements).Worth buying if you're comfortable with the price/hr ratio.

Game plays similar to predecessors. Due to it's pricing model, you can grab the game and the initial episode for a steal at 50% off in a sale to decide whether you like it enough to buy any more episodes or even the upgrade pack.So far I've enjoyed playing the first episode enough over the space of 6 hrs to buy the 2nd before the sale ends.As with my experience with the previous hitman games, takes me a few runs through a mission to get comfy enough to enjoy it.

In terms of gameplay No Mans Sky has several things going for it;It's famed procedural generation, there are many beautiful and diverse landscapes you can discover within this game.It's mysterious lore, as the game is newly released and the developers were quite tight lipped regarding the lore surrounding the game, there's quite a drive to unlock and discover many of the games secrets.However once you get past these things, the game comes down to being another waypoint collector with an (infinitely) large map, whether you are ok with that at this price is very subjective (there are lots of AAA titles with similar mechanics, this simply has a greater focus on exploration than combat).The game has several issues in it's current state. It currently freezes up fairly regularly during game-play for several seconds at a time and it also crashes out every few hours (it simply closes instantly, without showing an error or similar). If you do manage to play the game for ~4 hours straight without crashing, you might find that the FPS suddenly drops leaving the game unplayable until you close it and reopen (I'd guess this is caused by a memory leak).It seems very likely that these issues will however be worked out over time as the developers have committed to expanding the game with free dlc in the future.

This game is amazing. A mix of survival (in the sense that you must eat, you must have a varied diet to avoid certain immunity effects, you must stop things like bleeding, or fix broken bones, must sleep, stay hydrated, things along these lines) alongside traditional roguelike elements. A semi-randomly generated map, akin to something like Tales of Maj'Eyal, (in that some locations are never in the same location and are generated in a different location; leading to each playthrough and subsequent generation of your own playthroughs map feel unique) as well as a grid-based movement system, a health/mana bar, many different weapons of many different types, unique clothing and armor, differing classes with backstories and genders that effect how you are perceived in the world around you (For example, I am currently playing as a female sorcerer who is a mercenary; this is considered very strange in the games world and guards and others react to my characters presence accordingly). Speaking of magic, there are multiple different types of magic available should you choose to upgrade your character along those lines (Geomancy, Pyromancy, Cryomancy, Chronomancy, Electromancy, Venomancy, etc) all with their own pluses and minuses to how you might best utilize their strengths, leading to interesting player combination choices like a melee fighter that uses electromancy to buff their damage while using dual maces, giving the player the added benefits. Alongside the former I just mentioned the game is also beautiful. The pixel work is top notch, the sound design is amazing, I remember feeling genuinely intimidated upon entering the area a very powerful foe lurked in simply because the music set the mood of the fight and area so perfectly. This game is tough, but it is incredibly rewarding if you stick with it and learn from your mistakes. You're going to lose at first, but losing and getting knocked down is how you stand back up on your own two feet and learn to handle the next problem thrown at you. Don't get it twisted, I know there's a lot of people that aren't into punishing games, and this game might feel that way to someone unprepared, but if you take the time to learn the systems and think about the actions and moves you take, you will conquer this game through willpower and perseverance. Couldn't suggest the game enough, highly suggest you check it out.

Been playing this game for years, and the constant build up of content has only made to better the game, as this game gets further and further along in development and we close in on the date of the multiplayer release, this game will only continue to shine as one of the best, if not THE best "Zombie Survival Simulator" there is out there. Outstanding game, just make sure to either wait for the full release if you're looking for a multiplayer experience, or get it now and understand that the game is still under development. It's like a gem that's being cut, you must go through the appropriate steps in order to make it shine ---Let the devs give this gem the real luster it has the potential for!

Essentially the best game of this type to ever come out. This is more or less the magnum opus of this game genre and nothing even comes close to it. Honorable mention to Enter the Gungeon for being a fantastic game with a fantastic theme, but this game still takes the cake for the sheer quantity of characters, items, interactions, bosses, game modes, secrets, easter eggs and just about every other damn thing you could toss into a metric like that, the game has massive content, that cannot be denied, but besides just being packed to the brim it's also incredibly fun and strategic at the same time, getting used to all the of the different enemies and bosses gives you a sense of great progression when playing the game, and with the edition of some very hard secret characters that can be unlocked you can essentially choose your own difficulty level. Understanding the games general thought process behind secret room generation and the like can also be a huge boon in both the general amount of items you receive on a given play through, as well as that sweet, sweet feeling of further mastering the game on a deeper level.

When I originally purchased this game I was under the assumption that, yes, I would be able to purchase DLC, and that is fine, that's the prerogative of the creator of the game and I understand and believe that is fine. But with the addition of the recent "paid for mods" I honestly can say I don't believe I'll be making another purchase of anything related to TES. TES is, at it's heart in the eyes of the PC gaming community, a template. The game itself really is relatively lack luster, go from point A to point B and kill some Draugrs or Bandits along the way. The combat is weak and float-y and the story alongside characters and environments you deal with do not change or react differently when you defeated, what is supposed to be some world-ending dragon coming to destroy everything. But, with the addition of mods that you can download on top of DLC that the games creators have added you can give the game an entirely new perspective and how you want to play it. New schools of magic, new weapons, characters, outfits, entire other games in the series being recreated (Morrowind recreation project specifically) but the thing about those is that they are free, they are from the creators to share with the community. Mod creators are giving lifes blood to a game that, if it didn't have mods, would surely fall to the side of the other games in the PC gaming communities huge repertoire of games and mods to pick from. By charging for mods you are massively decreasing the available to content to a huge amount of people, people that may not HAVE the money to buy DLC, people who just want to play the game from a different perspective, or the infamous adult mods that I'm sure many of you know about. Paying for mods will only be a stake to the heart of the modding community on PC. By paying for mods, you are killing this. I can only hope that valve reconsiders this because it is frankly a very bad move for both Steam's workshop and community mod makers themselves.

I must say I am extremely disappointed in this game. If I hadn't been given this game for free I'd ask for a refund. My resolution isn't supported in full screen, so I can only play the game windowed, besides that there's a 20 second start up video you have to watch every time you open the game, and this cannot be turned off. Besides this, the controls are ridiculous. Who ever heard of a game needing backspace and enter for yes and no when half the other menus in the game allow you to use the mouse? This games just a cluster‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• of terrible execution. Very disappointed, I was looking for a good SHMUP and all I got was a waste of my time. Would NOT recommend this game

After almost half a year of absolutely ZERO meaningful content updates this game is now one of the few games I wish I could get my money back on. Whenever Chucklefish is done whiping it's ass with all the dollar bills it made off people ordering this maybe they'll actually finish the game they started.

I recommend this game. But I almost becoming more and more aware of it's issues.The fact that "skill based match making" is more of a lie then a truth, is pretty disturbing. Why throw someone who's only played for 2 days in with people who get 40 kills on average per game? That's absolutely no fun for someone just trying to understand and comprehend the physics and actions of the game on a level where you can actually compete against other decent players. I want to play this game a lot, I want to spend a lot of time in it, but it's really just no fun having to play against the same 20-30 people that are on the servers in my area every single day. I feel like my review would be much more positive if there were simply more people playing this game on a daily basis. Someone who's played this game for 5+ years has a major advantage over someone who's only just starting, and it really ruins what appears to be a really great game. I can't say that many other games have had genuine "skill based match making" but this game seems to completely throw that option out of the window. Where are the servers full of new players? Where are the servers for veterans to duke it out? I feel like if this trend of dealing with large portions of highly skilled players with no alternatives but to play against them are my only options, I may just stop playing. I want to like it, but the lack of actual players in decent amounts kills my interest daily.
Jesus christ, I don't even play this game, who the hell is updating this every single day? Can't even get on steam without this game updating. ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô?

Probably one of the most fun pixel games that has come out in an indeterminable amount of time.Do you want fun? Risk of RainDo you want to feel overpowered? Risk of RainDo you want to feel overpowered with your friends? Risk of RainDo you want to have a blast playing through a game that far exceeds the standards of a two-man developer team.Risk.Of.Rain.If there's one thing that's not a risk about this game, it's paying for it.

What a fantastic game, what is there to say? Not only does this game have one of the biggest skill trees that I have personally come acrossed in a video game, it is, in my humble opinion, the true Diablo 3, this game is immensely fun, and to think it's free, too. I couldn't have asked for a better combination of gameplay style and price.

I was skeptical about the new launcher, but didn't have to pay extra for the upgrade.  It provides easy access to great mods for the game, and even separates the saves by the content they're in, so everything stays nicely organized.  You're playing on a Unity port if you play the new version, but they based it all on the original engine, so it's also accurate.  It's a great way to play.
It's a great game, nice and relaxing.  You can play as intensely as you want and become a corn baron half the year, or just chill out, do what you want, and vibe.

Cool toy, and even the dev wants you to know that's all it is.  It's worth the money, tbh.  My one criticism is the tutorial could be more clear:  A text box telling you what you're doing, instead of freezing/warping time when you goof up.  I find that even more confusing, and am not 100% sure I know what I'm doing.  However, after you get past it, and just play a bit you start to get the hang of things.
I still think this is the best squad-based FPS ever.  It only has the 9 distinct characters, and creative loadouts.  After twelve years, it's still a favorite game to come back to.

GREAT GAME.  It's a very hands-on exploration game with beautiful planets, and a comfortable sense of adventure.  There's nothing to chase you down to kill you, but you'll want to be careful around some of the plants.  Nothing is particularly complicated, but if you get stuck the Astropedia (in-game reference) will help get you unstuck, but you can easily spend hours driving around amazing planets finding resources to build more stuff and eventually see the whole solar system.

If you've played Tetris Attack, Puzzle League in any if its forms, or Panel De Pon and liked any/all of those, you'll like this.  The story is standard for this sort of puzzle game, the puzzles get harder as you progress.  It's kinda cutesy, and the puzzles and challenges are tough.  If nothing else, on the competitive story matches, you can keep trying until the AI messes up.It's decently challenging, and has great Tetris Attack/Panel de Pon gameplay with variavble widths in the story.  It's a blast, well worth $4.

It's as good as everybody says it is.  If you like games like Transport Tycoon, you'll dig Factorio.There's a rush when you've started progressing that can't be beat, honestly, and it all just slowly snowballs until you've played 13 hours across a few days, building, optimizing, and building more to try to keep making progress.

It may be on the GZDoom, but it's nothing like Doom.  Honestly, it's more like Strife, with an actual story that unfolds as you play, reading scrolls scattered throughout the level.  There are some surprisingly intricate points in the game that can have you platforming, but they're rare.  I'm just impressed at how well designed the few spots you can do this feel.The weapons are great, you get a nice variety, you can throw your axe and RECOVER IT.  The shotgun is great (some boomer shooters have a problem with meh shotgun, Zan got it right on this), the rifle even works great.  The alternate weapons feel good, and add crazy dimensions, like the time crystals or the elemental ring.If you want to play a very original shooter, this is a good shot, well worth the price whatever it sits at.  I didn't get it on sale, and it's great.  You may get stuck a few times, I just got bogged down on combat, but it's a great game.It only has one episode, with another in progress, so I'll update my review whenever that happens, but even right now, it's well worth what you pay for it.

I've got a short playtime on this one because I actually bought it on Itch.  I liked it so much I bought it on Steam.The trailers make it look like a randomized Legend of Zelda, and in the best ways, it absolutely is. It is designed to be replayable, the endings have to be acheived in certain specific ways, and this game, especially later, gets a depth like Link to the Past, but it's still not right to compare it to the series it also directly parodies.This game is worth the money, is a complete blast, and I look forward to replaying it with some experience behind me.

Excellent physics, the trick system is great.  it's the best game that is at all like the Tony Hawk series, but on bicycles.  The racing is excellent, combos are easy to pull off (but still require skill), and it's an extremely fun and satisfying game to play with massive replayability.

I like this game a lot. I've been playing it on and off for quite some time. There's a lot to do. Combat is fun. Space trucking is cool too, if you don't mind how soul-sucking it can get. Mining is also a lot of fun, sometimes. And the things you see if you bother to go exploring, even just a little bit, can be breathtaking. But the grind is terrible. Just awful. So bad in fact, that it detracts significantly from all the cool stuff I mentioned. Playing this game is a certain kind of masochism. This makes Elite: Dangerous my favourite game that I have a hard time recommending people.

Enjoying this thoroughly. I remember seeing the trailer for it however many years ago. "Wow! Factorio, but 3D!" I was then, promptly disappointed to see it discover it an Epic exclusive. Well, now it's finally on Steam, and I can play it.  Satisfactory is not Factorio in 3D. Satisfactory's approach to progression and logistics is very different. That's perfectly fine, and is all very well implemented. I still however, can't shake the feeling that something is a little off. I think Satisfactory's logistics systems are a bit too simple (maybe easy would be a better word, idk) for my liking, at least when compared to Factorio. So, it's pretty good, but I think Factorio is better. This doesn't really matter, but it's something to consider.
It's fun and fairly polished. Still suffers from its share of bugs and weird quirks. Story sucks big time.

Main story is nothing to call home about but is relatively fun. Martial arts combat is fun and satisfying, but the gunplay (what little there is of it) is basic at the very best. Of the story DLCs, nightmare in northpoint feels the most fleshed out but it's very short. the year of the dragon is short and the story is a joke, would not recommend the DLC. main game is fun, like GTA in hong kong

The game is very pretty, but ultimately didn't hold my interest enough for me to finish it. The game does some interesting things with time manipulation mechanics, but somehow, even with that, the gameplay feels basic at best and boring at worst. The interruptions by the in-game TV show ruin the whole flow of the game when you have to watch a 15 min cutscene to get to the next gameplay segment. It was an interesting try, but ultimately smushing a TV show and a game together just doesn't work. If you're looking for a game similar to this, try out Control. Same developers and is WAY more polished and enjoyable to play. If you came here from control looking for a similar game, this isn't it.
The combat system in this game is very fun. But don't come into this game expecting an amazing story, because you're not going to find it here.

I somewhat reluctantly can't recommend this game. I played and enjoyed the other two games in the rebooted series so I finished this one out of the need to see the story end. And that was the problem, it felt like a chore to play every time i booted it up. that being said it's not a bad game, It's very pretty and has the usual cool puzzle mechanics. but it did feel like the bow was WAY too favored a weapon in this game, with almost no time devoted to the other weapons in the game. As for the plot, well despite the fact that the fate of the world is literally at stake in this game, it really felt like it didn't have any stakes until the very last mission. If you played and liked the other two games, i'd recommend it just to finish the story. if you were lukewarm on the other two games, you should definitely give this a pass

This isn't a bad game, however it's ot a good game either. it has a fairly neat mechanic, where you can either stop, slow, or reverse time. It's implemented fairly well but it honestly feels like they could have done more with it.  The story is easily the weakest part. you play as (as far as i could tell) a random scientist who goes back in time to stop another scientist who stole a timesuit and created a dystopian reality in the 1930's much like wolfenstein. you end up working for a resistance leader who's name is mentioned so little that i've forgotten it entirely. there isn't a single character with a shred of personality in this entire story, there aren't really any supporting players so to speak.   The game is also fairly short, clocking in at around 8 hours If you like shooters with interesting mechanics, then this might be for you, but if you're like me and enjoy a good story I can't recommend this game at all.

The gameplay is fun at first but gets EXTREMELY repetitive, with no enemy variation. there's only two different guns (though they each have five different modes if you want to get technical) and the "Story" is somehow super simple and way too confusing at the exact same time. and the "Cutscenes" are just the storyboards with some basic animations attached to them; while that may be ok for some, it just feels lazy to me. It would work if the rest of the game was stylized like that, but then it snaps back into the realistic graphics of the gamplay, the effect is super jarring. For what it's worth, it does look pretty and blowing up enemies is pretty fun. If you're into games with not a lot of story and repetitive enemy onslaughts then maybe pick this game up when it's on sale. If not, don't bother, this game isn't for you.

I enjoyed this game a lot!  Pros:-combat is fun -has a varitety of different attacks and rewards you for using them. -the humor actually made laugh out loud a few times-the character develoipment is quite good Cons:-not exactly a con, but the controls are a little clunky at first but you get used to it as the game goes on-the story is a little generic and the way it is presented is a little hard to follow-my biggest complaint of all is that for whatever reason, the menus sometimes take an eternity to pop up. like when you pause the game it sometimes take 1-20 seconds to pop up. disabling V-sync help with this a little but it was still really badOverall I had a great time with this game! would definitely reccomend

Eh, For whatever reason this game didn't do it for me. I only played a little of it if im going to be totaly honest. the destruction was fun and the driving controlled well. I think the biggest thing that prevented me from getting into it was the story and the characters. the characters were flat and dull and i had no emotional investment in any of them. and the story is one giant cliche "New guy arrives on mars, tragedy befalls him, he inexplicably becomes the new face of the revolution."TL:DR good game play, weak storyline and characters

I had fun playing it but I would not recommend it to others, it's not worth your time. 6/10 proaly will not play again.

If you've played Insurgency mechanically this is a lot like that.  Except the guns are really bad.  They feel immensely satisfying to use, they're just either inaccurate or have miserably slow rates of fire.This is awesome, because having bad guns forces the players to get up closer to eachother, switching the focus of the combat to mid and short range encounters.  Running headlong into danger feels less like suicide, and more like a risky play.

I'll be honest. We're gonna miss this game. It was a prime example of 2k's ignorance at a great IP and fishering away their team for a flop of a sequel that was borderlands 3. Gear box did amazing with this game dispite all its flaws at launch, the game slowly became more stable by the middle of its life, but the playerbase never seemed to returned. Only a fair share of people who loved it came back and it had a wonderful and small community making fan art and writing fiction. I got too know some of the roleplay community who wrote and exspanding on the adventures of Solus and the small dying last star. I fairly enjoyed this most out of the "Hero-Shooter" Genre that spawned out 4 years ago. Yet this game got overshadowed and unfairly compared to Blizzards Overwatch. Battleborn was the more unique and interesting of the two because of the characters and world building and the actual Campaign you played. We could have gotten more if Gearbox stuck to battleborns development. Sadly they had to make the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• 3rd entry in Borderlands and well thats how things fell apart.My freind Captain Chaos has a better explanation of the game-play perspective of Battleborn, I'm not good at leaning into a large writing of how it works but to sum it up. You have alot of characters with diffrent gimmicks and roles, they level up while you play the levels, like some MOBA's let you. You can choose between 2 choices per level in a augment tree and eventually unlock augments with leveling the character on your player profile. Every character is amazing in their own way. Except Kid Ultra.Anyways I love this game to bits and as a farewell I have written this reveiw/letter of goodbye thing. I'm sad to see it go.

I used to think VR was just a gimmick... Not anymore.If you're like me and thought VR is too expensive, look up Samsung HMD Odyssey+ Windows Mixed Reality Headset on Amazon. Excellent game, best "internet simulator" I've ever played, having played quite a few. I'm sure I've missed some stuff so I'll be going back to it eventually, and there's definitelly a lot of missable secrets and such in this.Overall plot is great and interesting, but the real best part of it is the characters you read about from just their simple webpages in the game and see how they change over time.Solid 9/10, some of the puzzles in the game were very vague on how to even start solving them and it got me frustrated occasionally, but aside from that it's a fantastic game.

Probably one of, if not THE best RPGmaker/RPGmaker-style game I've ever played. The battle system is both unique and also recognizable with its simple yet deep and customizable nature. The story is not that grandiose until maybe the end, but that's really all it needed to be, a comfy heartwarming plot that hits where it needs to. The graphics are also great, with a sort of mixture of Pokemon, Mother 3, and some of it's own really nice style (especially in the portrait art and drawn art in the credits).While it may not have blown up like similar games such as Undertale, HEARTBEAT definitelly does a better job at both its message and gameplay. As well as being much less linear then other "mother 3 type games". For only $15, it's honestly a steal as I've gotten over 60 hours out of it, and I'm not even finished the postgame/bonus content. All in all this game deserves more people to play through it.

I love the Lego games and Lego Star Wars, but this.. just isn't a Lego game.I understand that when this came out people were saying how Lego games were getting stale, and so Travellers Tales decided to change up the gameplay, the problem is what they changed it too is a boring sub-RTS with some normal levels sprinkled in. I've only played 3 levels all of which were short and boring, if they had only made this game with similar but updated gameplay from the last 2 games, it would've been perfect. Note, that even if you love the cartoon, it's still not worth it, I recommend just getting the Complete Saga, an older but much better game then this.

Pros:+Combines RPG battles with top down shooters perfectly+Some of the best humor in video games+Perfectly blends humor and drama+Amazing soundtrack+Your choices actually matter, even in multiple playthroughs+True ending feels like a true ending, it leaves no room for a prequel or a sequel, which is what a good story should do.+Dogs!Cons:-There's really no challenge to the game besides the final bosses (Yes, plural, can't really explain without spoiling)-Short, even with the multiple playthroughs-Certain areas of the game's world can be tedious, even on a first playthroughOverall Undertale is an extremely enjoyable experience and my personal game of the year. If you play this game show it to everyone you know, make them play it. If they don't play video games tell them to watch a playthrough on youtube, because the story is something everyone should experience. In conclusion Undertale is an amazing game, play it. 10/10 I personally can't wait for whatever Toby Fox (this game's developer) makes next.

Pros:+The strategy in this game is not too deep, and not too simple, great for newcomers to the genre, but hardcore strategy gamers might find it too simple compared to paradox's games+Nice looking graphics, ecspecially for a 2010 game+You have alot of options each time you start a new game, from what the world looks like, how big or small it is, how many civs are in the game, how slow or fast the ingame years progress, and much more+Each civ feels unique, and its hard to pick what civ you want to be at the start of a new game because of the great benefits you get from each+The DLC is some of the best, and is totally worth itCons:-On easier difficulties, theres always those civs that want to be your friend really bad, and civs who are basically hitler (ironic, since he's not one of the civs in the game), and the hitler civs always just bulldoze the friendly, pitiful civs to get to you, this is more balanced on high difficulties though-Really long loading on startup-Can get glitchy on bigger worlds-WHY DOES RUSSIA LOVE TO SETTLE SO CLOSE TO MEOverall fantastic game, a must buy 9/10Also buy the DLC

The simple premise of this game belies its brilliance as a strategy game. It is an elemental battle between choice and luck.One request I have for the developer is to add an infinite mode. I thought that was what I was buying when I got this. I can't believe how much I like the strategy but it would be cool to have a thoughtless version. Maybe your score in the limited-roll mode could help you in your infinite-roll run. Even if the game stays in its current state, it will always be worth the price of admission.

I haven't played a lot of this current version but it is definitely an improvement from the free version. There is a lot more to do and build and there is an amazing soundtrack. The graphics have improved as well. The ocean in this game is actually frightening because the waves can get big and the omni-present shark looks and acts real enough. I don't know if I can reccomend this game to anyone but definitely to those in need of a fresher survival game.

Dead cells is a really fun game. It is an action platformer that features a lot of items with seemingly endless combinations of perks on them. It features many upgrades and has really responsive movement. $20 does seem like a bit much at the moment but if this is the type of game you like, then it is definitely worth it.

Is this game absolutely everything I ever wanted it to be? No. Is it still great? Absolutely. I think the bar was set very high for this game, and even though it didn't quite reach it, the game is still great, definitely better than 2 and 3. This is of course my opinion, but I think the skill point system is excellent. I understand why it has caused some controversy in the community but I think it fits pretty well and still holds its excellent weapon and enemy balance. The legion system is truly one of a kind and epic even if its a little disappointing in how often it occurs. I know the story focus is something different when it comes to Serious Sam, but for their first attempt I think Croteam did a great job. The characters are okay, some better than others and they serve their purpose in the story well enough. There were plenty of lines of dialogue that gave me a genuine chuckle (like the Rodriguez joke Jones makes). The story can be a bit iffy in spots, and semi-predictable. In spite of this there were some twists and other beats that genuinely surprised me. I do, however, agree that the story is the weakest part of the game, but its still passable and is very Sammy. Let's be honest though, most of us aren't in it for the story. We're in it for the guns, enemies, and gameplay that we all know and love, and that is certainly present. I cannot wait for the community to get their hands on the modding tools when the workshop goes live. The Serious Sam community is full of passionate and creative people and I can't wait to see what comes out of it.

This is a tough one, if there was a mixed review option I'd choose that.Playing in VR with a Hotas. The VR is done superbly, but the integration with a Hotas, in particular the key mapping is just utterly appalling. Frequent soft crashes if a key isn't mapped to a particular key require constant re-mapping - which really distracts from experience. This seems to be a common complaint. Devs have clearly focused on controller play, but (like ED) really comes into it's own in VR with a stick. Real shame.When it's running, it's a fun game. But setting it up is an ongoing nightmare.

I don't review games very often, but this was an excellent game, I couldn't put it down! I was late to the party and this only came to my attention when Ninja Theory ported this to VR - I haven't played in VR yet, but this would be incredible.I love Ninja Theory titles and this was reminded me of Heavenly Sword, but with a deeper plot and I actually feel for the protagonist. It's short, but well worth it for the ¬£20 mark.Definitely play with a quality set of 3D headphones as these have been optimised for

This has been in my library for 5 years - can't believe I just got round to playing it!Game is basically a point and click decision and consequence (like a telltale) with retro graphicsIt' repetitive, but that's actually the point and relates to the plot, which was pretty good for such a small game!
Makes me feel like I'm 10, playing on my Amiga 600 again!

Excellent game, not really played anything quite like it. Merger of a 3rd person hack & slash, shooter and RPG. Very different way to tell a story, especially the ending. I particularly liked the switching between 3D, isometric and 2D perspectives.

It's a shooter such as Battlefield with some basic survival elements, gathering guns etc on a huge map, with a decreasing play area - players are forced into an ever reducing play space.It's really awesome! Perfect balance of survival and gunplay for quick games!EDIT, removed the Don't Starve ref - yea it's pretty misconceiving!!!

Vive strapped to my face, I'm coming into land, I'm in the pipe, 5 by 5 and I feel my phone vibrate. I pick it up, offer it upto my face. It's not there and I frown confused for a few seconds before I realise I'm not really flying a spaceship! This game was made for VR.FYI I have many more hours in from before the game was on steam, somewhere in the region of 500 at the time of writing.Like so many have already said, you have to like space! Its very spacey! All the negative reviews revolve around the grind and lack of any storyline and this is why I'm writing this. Elite is a simulator and NOT an arcade game, you won't be shooting aliens in 5 minutes, you have to be prepared to work for your rewards. The missions have improved, but it's still very much "do you own thing", you set your own goals.As a minimum, you need a HOTAS! Add a headset and the level of immersion is unrivaled. The community is the best I've ever encountered.The dev team are still adding content and have a definitive road map and listen to their customers. Its never too late to start playing.See you in the black!
It's rare I review a game... but this was the reason I cancelled my Oculus for the Vive! This had me literally ducking and diving all over the living room. Really really good fun!

I've played a bit of the legacy version which I loved, but have really come on board with the new spruced up graphics (experimental) version - I guess I'm a sucker for eye candy! I've never followed a game development before, but every week I'm geninuely excited at what has been added to this game. There is so much potential, you could spend your life on it!It's very rare a game will leave me with my heart pounding when sometime is chasing me with a spear or defending my newly build dream home! Flip side, there's nothing more gratifying than sneaking up on someone, bashing his skull in with a rock and taking his favorite axe!I must admit the game is poorly optimised, I play this on a VERY high spec machine and get comparably poor framerates, but I lets be fair, this is alpha.

Despite all the raging and mishaps that occurred during my adventure as a lowly tarnished trying to become the Elden Lord, I can safely say this was one of the best experiences in gaming I've ever had. However, some performance issues can be quite frustrating at times. All in all, amazing game and From Soft really outdid themselves this time. (Side note: If you want to experience pain don't use magic, also worth mentioning I believe this is the way this game is meant to be played)

This game is a waste of time, literally, 20 of my 70 hours were spent waiting for queues. At the start the game feels fun and the story actually seems to be interesting, however, the gameplay becomes repetitive pretty fast, specially in PVE. Well you might say, just play PVP lmao, let's say I did, there are classes that outshine others in every aspect, even if you do master the dodge mechanic or "git gud". Sorceress, for example, has very safe skills with high dmg and low cooldown, whereas most characters have high cooldowns on their abilities with the most dps. You could also, for instance, focus on PVE only, but you will notice why this is not as viable as you thought initally once you reach endgame, since most PVE content is locked behind a specific gear level, which you can only upgrade witch chaos dungeons. Why is this a problem, you ask, you can only get gear 2 times a day through chaos dungeons. This doesn't mean you can't keep doing them, however, the progress will be MUCH MUCH slower, since you get certain materials that can be traded weekly, however these trades are ALSO CAPPED. Imo, the hype for this game was desperate and baseless, every hour of my gameplay I thought why this game was any different from other MMO's and I couldn't really find an answer. The pay to win argument is false due to the pvp being equalized for all players, but that doesn't change the fact that if you want to progress faster in terms of PVE you have to pay. Let's be honest here, the main motivation behind MMO's is progressing, most of the times, even if combat feels boring you push through because you want to progress and become stronger. The game stops you from doing so which, in my opinion, is frustrating and stupid. TLDR, servers are extremely bad, PVE is underwhelming, repetitive and capped, PVP, in the current state, has classes that clearly outshine others, with some of them being completely useless. (If you want a game to bust your kneecaps and stop you from progressing just go play genshin impact kek)*If you like the game, keep playing, just wanted to share my "unpopular" opinion (68% positive reviews)*

Game was pretty fun for the first 25-30 hours, however I feel the game could do so much more if the developer just went ahead and hired a team to be able to release new content asap. There seem to be "updates" coming out for this game, but they're just bug fixes and that's not enough to keep the fun going, specially in a game like this one where it can become very repetitive in so little time.

In an ocean of deck building rogue-lites, Banners of Ruin somehow manages to find its own identity and it can uphold a certain charm. It certainly is a bit too sluggish and quirky at times but the visual style and uniqueness of the combination of certain mechanics such as party members sharing a hand can be interesting to play around with. Give it a try if you are into the genre.
A very generous card collection game with gorgeous artwork.

This is the first game from the JRPG genre I have tried. I really like the way this game is implemented, I enjoy characters' arcs and combat is very enjoyable once you get used to it. If you are considering buying this game I would say it definitely deserves a chance even if you haven't played anything like it before.

A very good game that manages to combine different styles and game mechanics into one game masterfully. The first game was a very nice different game, and this sequel did improve on many things. Recommended to anyone who enjoys a nice singleplayer experience.

This spaceship management rogue-like game has introduced me into a whole new genre since I mostly prefer games, books and movies with fantasy settings and the games I play mostly consist of rpg elements. While this game is neither of those, i am now a fan of this title. I love the music, the writing and most importantly; gameplay. It seems hard and frustrating to progress in the game but when you start to learn the details and grasp the mechanics there is a lot to discover. The replayibility is astounding with all procedurally generated runs, vast array of events, all kinds of ships and crew. If you have been thinking about giving this game a try, go ahead and buy this gem.

A short but enjoyable little game that gives you a cinematic experience with some mini puzzles thrown in. I recommend this game if you like a story driven small game since it offers a nice experience that will be worthy of your time. Bonus: It is very fun to play with someone in the same room.

This is one of the most underrated games I have played, this game is a colourful turn based rpg with great replayiblity. If you think you would enjoy a turn based rpg/strategy game with cartoonish features and a twist of rock, paper & scissors in it, give it a try!
Impressive writing with fun combat and progression system that can keep a player immersed in the game for hours. Highly recommended as it is a well made game.
The best game I have ever played yet.

Stardew Valley is a very enjoyable game. It has a good mannered developer who keeps the game fresh with updates which already has a lot of content you can enjoy for a long time. It feels like this game contains a lot for an indie project. I recommend this masterpiece wholeheartedly.

I like to think I am an even-tempered man. I don't honk at the guy in front of me when I'm stuck in traffic, and I grumble only mildly at inclement weather. With that in mind, this game has made me rage-quit only to start it back up hours later multiple times. You will want to tear your hair out with frustration, but you will keep coming back for more. And I mean that in the best possible sense.

This game has been in development for quite some time. Since the last time I played it, the UI has somewhat improved, as did the model assets. However, that is where the improvements seem to end. The game environments are about as bland and generic as can be, with levels of quality that would look bad ten years ago, let alone today. Optimization is poor to nonexistant, with my framerate staying below 30 even on the thoughtfully included "Minimal" graphics settings - which I shouldn't have to resort to while using a Radeon 390. While not much can be expected of a small game studio, this title is just not up to par with the likes of Robocraft or Mechwarrior Online.

I can't say I had any expectations of any kind when I picked this up. I kinda just wanted to see what the heck it was. I have to give it a positive review though. While the... premise.. is what it is, the card based gameplay is genuinely interesting and fun. I would recommend looking at the workshop for more and better cards though. Managing the various.. ahh.. resources available is also a decent challenge so it doesn't feel like you're just endlessly clicking through things to get to the next "scene".There are some negatives though. There is no 3440*1440 resolution option, the FOV is annoyingly low (you can apparently get bonuses that increase the FOV by very small increments), and the refresh rate has to be pretty low. I haven't had an FPS counter up while playing yet but after about an hour or so my eyes need a break and if you are sensitive to it it could give you a headache after a while. There seems to be a minor bug in that if you play certain cards with animations that interrupt the turn you can't click any cards or end turn until the animation completes.In the "would be nice" category I would prefer if more effort were put into the various scenes available (higher res, more realistic, etc though I also get that there is a definite artistic style to this and that could be  seen as a legit reason to have them as is). You can click past the ones you have already seen but there is so little variety to them you eventually want to just skip past most of them but watching them is tied to one of the resources you need to progress. Also the "Temptation" card is fun to use but weirdly a lot of the enemies are immune to it, presumably because they didn't do the necessary animations, yet those same enemies do have end scenes if you win the battle. Also can get a little grindy after a while. Not mobile "You work for us now" grind, but enough to get old. Having 4 mana to start and a few more health gain cards would really help smooth that out I think.Overall this is genuinely fun to play and there is more to it than you probably think.

All I can say is that I love this game. The art and music are really beautiful and you will actually feel bad when you zoom out for the sake of seeing where villages, ruins, and anomalies are. The difficulty scale takes a little getting used to and you have to be a little careful getting to know which quests to take on and which to not worry about. When I was first starting out I sort of rushed a faction quest that expects you to be a lot higher level in the game in terms of units and weaponry so it spawned a scripted army right on my city that I had absolutely no way of dealing with. That can be maddening at first but once you get a feel for things it's fine. Be patient, enjoy the ambiance. This game is a great buy at regular price but it goes on sale pretty often so if you haven't played this and you can pick it up, I highly recommend. Of the DLC my personal must have would be Tempest but they all kind of depend on what your playstyle is and what you personally are looking for. I would start there though.

Probably one of the most "complete" paradox games to be released in a while. Compared to CK2 there's a lot you might miss, but CK2 has been out there a while with a lot of expansions to it. Now, like a lot of people into PDX games I have to join the chorus on saying I really have a distaste for their expansion and DLC model. While you don't *need* them, they do what they can, I think purposefully, to make you really feel like you're missing a lot without them. They have a history of taking elements of what was in the base game, then moving that and expanding on it in a DLC to where the base game doesn't function the way it once did. Not that you can't still play and have fun, but it's annoying.I would always recommend PDX games but definitely wait for a big sale to pick up most of their games. CK3 is in fact one of the few in their library that I would say is worthy of picking up sale or no. It's better to save some cash but if you pay full price I don't think you'll feel ripped off or anything.I really enjoy CK3 but one final sort of gripe I have is that I see people starting chains of events and storylines that I don't know how to get started and the requirements for the various events aren't explained in the game at all. Probably you need to read a WIKI or something and I would prefer if these events were divulged to the player in the game. When an event fires, maybe some context saying "This happened because of X and Y". I dunno. While frustrating sometimes it's not bad being surprised when crazy things happen.

This game is great. Sure, I have no idea what I'm doing, but neither do most of the other reviewers so that seems fine! Seriously this is fun and you can get really pulled into it, but be prepared to do a little homework and check out some lets plays or something. I personally wouldn't worry about achievements right off. Find good mods on the workshop to make the game a whole lot better and play to have a good time. When you get a feel for how things work, try ironman without mods if you want to.Recommended, but like most Paradox games, due to their DLC being priced too high and making changes to base game that almost make DLC required to be playable, wait for a good sale.

The nostalgia is strong with this one. The only thing I really miss is the music, but a patch added that. I just had to find the soundtrack in OGG format and put it in /Quake II RTX/baseq2/music.I'm playing this with an Asus 1080Ti Strix OC gaming card. I might not be getting the full experience because to get a playable framerate I have to crank things way down to 800x600 or so. I avg about 40 fps there. But you know, that's about what my experience was when this was new and I was in college anyway. I can't *not* recommend Quake 2. But that's more because of what it means to me personally. It's a good time. Worth the $5. You'll get more out of this than a big mac at McDonalds, you know?
I don't like the DLC model, but the game is pretty interesting if you're the right kind of person.  Watch tutorials online or you'll be completely lost though.
Try this game! It's quick and the humor is good. You can never take your pants off though...

I'm coming from a background with the board game Star Fleet Battles. Some jiggering was needed to translate this into an entertaining computer game, but I think they did a really good job. Im playing this on Sabayon Linux 4.14.0 with the new steamplay proton tool. I had to manually edit an .ini file to get the driver to render with hardware instead of software, and set the resolution to something reasonable, but that isn't the fault of the game. I'd recommend it if you ever wanted to command a star trek based ship. There's no Spock, Kirk, or Scotty- They didn't have the license for that. All the ship designs  are true to the show though, having been licened via Amarillo Design Bureau, who obtained the ship design licensing from Franz Joseph and the Star Trek Technical Manual.

We are well past the "Augment your pre-order" fiasco. I picked this up on sale with the season pass for about $30. For that I would say it's well worth it. In game credits and "scrap" for crafting come fairly slowly and feels a little grindy to me-these are things you can buy with real money from the game store. You could also theoretically increase those items with some sort of third party tool... I wouldn't want to break any terms of service here by recommending something like that because it's a *cheat* and may not be permitted in reviews but freedom of speech is the *engine* that drives us in the USA, yeah? Oh, one thing really dislike is single-use microtransaction and DLC items. I am sure this issue has been discussed enough so I won't repeat what others have said, but it IS exploitative and inexcusable. But as that third party tool theoretically may exist... it doesn't have to be that big of a problem. Also if you only plan to play the came to completion once and move on to a new game, well, it doesn't matter really. That doesn't make the practice acceptable though.      Praxis is less grindy, especially if you get extra XP hacking and exploring, finding alternate routes to objectives, etc. I did a lot of side quests before I really got into the main story arc so they came a little slow for me, but once I started the main and got into it they started adding up. I would recommend taking L5 hacking as soon as you can if you don't mind the hacking minigame. Once you have that the XP from it really snowballs and praxis adds up.     I have honestly not gone far into the game yet but the story so far is good enough that I am curious enough about it to continue. If you read a lot of the emails and pocket secretary text you do start to second guess and wonder whose side is "better" to be on. The racism theme makes you think about things without (In my opinion anyway) being preachy or overbearing.     Performance-wise when I first started playing I cranked everything to ultra on a 1080Ti Strix OC and it was *very* choppy with a framerate around 30-40 at 3440x1440. I tried to lower the resolution and cut some less important (to me) settings but on full screen you could tell that menus weren't being displyed correctly, like the top and bottom of the screen had been cut off rather than resized. After some searching I discovered that MSAA is the culprit. If you have performance issues, turn it off. I am now running evertyhing on max with MSAA off at 3440x1440 and getting a pretty steady 60fps.      I played breach just long enough to get the free praxis for single player mode. It is otherwise awful and boring. Go through the tutorial as it takes about 15 minutes then forget it exists. They clearly just jammed it in to farm micro transaction money complete with "Oh shiny card packs glitter and sparkle" animations, obviously trying to leach on Hearthstone, but failing.     Over all for the sale cost at $30 I would recommend this game without reservation.
REV UP THOSE FRYERS, I mean servers. Friendship with VRChat ended, ChilloutVR is my new best friend.
Feels really nice, am enjoying so far. Difficult as expected. Had some performance issues at first, but updating my nvidia drivers seemed to fix the issue.

First impressions are that this game falls very short of what I was hoping for. I thought the first game was fantastic. I am very much a "Don't fix what ain't broken" kinda person and unfortunately with this sequel, they changed a lot of the core mechanics. Melee combat feels weak and unsatisfying, blows to zombies don't have that oomph they had in the first game. The parkour seems to be lacking, I didn't find it as fun as the first game. The interface is HOT GARBAGE, can't tweak basic video settings or even remap controls. That along with the game being hard capped at 60 fps with vsync and the terrible optimization, this feels like a piss poor console port. I am going to wait for the reviews to come out about the story and from pro reviewers before I make a decision but I will most likely refund. Very Disappointed, but glad I didn't pre-order.

Really, really, really fun. The game Post Scriptum should have been. It has the team based dynamics of Squad and the gritty, hell-on-earth gameplay/graphics of Red Orchestra/Rising Storm. If you are a fan of either of those titles, you'll love this game. Each round is absolute mayhem in the front, organized in the rear, and feels like two teams throwing haymakers at each other. The game's community is very friendly to new players, just stick to rifleman and drop ammo boxes until you learn the ropes before trying out other classes. Game is very populated with up to 20+ full 50v50 (NA/EU) servers at peak hours (12pm-12am) US EST.

Love this game and the whole series despite the flaws. Don't care what anyone says.

These are two of my favourite games of all time, 999 is worth the price alone but you get two fantastic games remastered for the price of one. They are both pretty simple, well made puzzle games with a lot of story in between. The puzzles aren't groundbreaking but they do require you to think which is honestly better than 99% of puzzles you get in video games nowadays. The multiple timelines and different endings are worked into the game so well and your choices really do matter, your actions actually have consequences and you feel it. The best part of the games is just going through all the different endings and seeing all the different outcomes. The writing is fantastic, there is an incredible amount of detail and depth when it comes to the storytelling. Sadly not many people are aware of these gems because they originally only came out on the Nintendo DS, but they really are fantastic games so I feel like I should recommend them. The English voice acting is truly wonderful, make sure you play with the English voices instead of the Japanese ones, you can tell the voice actors had so much fun making this. Its got a perfect balance of playfulness, humour and seriousness. Give it a shot.

It's free and very short with some really outstanding artwork. It only takes an hour and a half to get all 4 endings but every ending is unique. Also if you like lesbians like me then this game has gay girls so thats another bonus. It's free and short, definitley worth playing.

It's a VERY short game, it's not got much gameplay other than the navigating with your compass and exploring. What the game does have going for it is some of the best writing/voice acting you will ever come across. You can't help but end up falling in love with Delilah, a 46 year old women where you don't even know what she looks like. It's relaxing, but it's not worth buying at full price. Get it when it's cheap on sale (IT'S ON SALE NOW, ONLY LIKE $3)

This might be the best survival horror/action game since Resident Evil 4. Basically this is Resident Evil 4 with A LOT LEES action and MUCH MORE survival horror. I've always loved survival horror games and this one does it right. Wasting a bullet or not keeping an eye on inventory space can really screw things up for you. This is the perfect remake for RE2. It's scary, INCREDIBLY TENSE, looks absolutely gorgeous, has some wonderful Resident Evil voice acting and did I mention that they decided to put 4 different campaigns that I still haven't even finished. Not to mention all of the bonus content. There is perhaps 1 or 2 well earned jumpscares but the real horror comes when you see all the zombies coming towards you but you are out of ammo while also being chased by this creepy guy called Mr. X. I really adore this game and this is how combat based survival horror games should be made.

Was a fun experience, music was good, animations were great, and I really loved the art style. It was fun being a horrific monster for change and devouring every living thing in your way. The game makes you strategize, you can't just be a giant monster all the time and you're still vulnerable to overwhelming enemies and you need to plan things out. There is some story but the game tries to keep thing on track with the violence and puzzles.The only complaints I would have are maybe the game is too short, it took four hours to beat but maybe some might not see that as an issue. I really didn't know about the extra upgrades unless I accidentally stumbled on them and completely forgot to even go back for them. I pretty much beat the game with just the regular upgrades and only a few extra ones.Overall though the game is pretty fun and I would definitely recommend.

Okay here's the situation: you and a friend are playing co-op together, your friend is the host. As long as your friend is aware of your burning passion for shovels.10/10

They have created a refined version of the original mod, and made it more realistic along with adding workshop support to allow it to feel more like the original. I feel like other than adding planes and helicopters there isn't much they can do at all. It is definitely fun and enjoyable to play and I 100% feel I will be playing this for many years to come and that is really all I can ask for with a game.

Having only around 4 hours in the game at the writing of this review, I have to say, this game is really beautiful.Scenery looks real enough for me to think it's taken from a real place.

I love the art style, I love the music, I love everything about this game, except the controls. Obviously it's just my opinion, but after playing it for 0.3 hours, I got frustrated at the controls. I'll still give it a thumbs up for it being a good game, I just despise the controls.

Beautiful. Just beautiful. I'd tell my opinion on the story now that it's out, but my pc keeps crashing when I play this (Or VR, might be too much for this old machine). But I highly recommend buying this. It's an amazing indie title that everyone should play. And it's fairly cheap too.I highly suggest for you to buy this masterpiece.

If you're thinking about buying this game as your first ever 3D fighter, don't even touch the multiplayer until you've learned combos or such. Everyone who plays multiplayer seem to have too much time on their hands, but still seem like they just want to win for winning. Doesn't matter if you play on manual or normal, ranked and unranked is awfully unbalanced, due to the lack of players and actual consideration for a fair fight. You either fight a champion whose played the game since it was released and lost his job because of it, or someone new spamming the square. It would be so much better, if the devs made so that your opponents would be atleast close to the level of skill you are instead of picking the fighter whose ready right at that moment. And let's not talk about how furiating the multiplayer bug was on launch.The game does have some good qualities of course. The game has great controls, graphics and all together mood. It feels like a fighting game when you actually fight. Customization could be better and have more options, but eh, that's just a minimal problem I have.I hope more people would buy this on pc and actually play it. The peak player count at the moment of me writing this is 1243, With current players being only 89. So if you buy this and decide to play the multiplayer right away, be prepared for alot of unfair matches, especially if you're new. And I'd say wait for a sale on the game. 60$ is alot of money and for a game like this, it's too much.TLDR; Be ready to get your ass kicked in this okay My Hero Academia fighting game.

I love this game and after putting in nearly 1000 hours I'm still having fun! I thought I'd get bored of robbing banks after like 200 hours, but since they keep adding content quite frequently, it has been interesting. You start by robbing a small bank and move to the big scores. And the game is what? 40‚Ç? You get so much content with such a low price compared to most AAA titles. I'm glad Overkill keeps updating the game until the end of 2018 (Atleast from what I've heard).But everything good has something bad in them, so I'll be listing some pros and cons.Pros:-Fairly cheap-Multiple difficulties so new players can get the hang of it-Customizable masks-Weapons, oh the wonderful weapons!-New content added quite often-Alot of heistsCons:-Crashes quite often compared to other games-Those who bought the DLC before it was packed in the Ultimate Edition lose alot of money-Few bugs here and there, nothing critical though-Some heists are repetive and awfully long in some situationsSo, I thought of something Overkill could add to the gameMask Workshop:Let the community create masks for the gameOver all, Payday 2 is a 8/10 in my opinion. If you're feeling like you could rob some banks, cook meth, take down rats, help your old friend out of jail or anything that could be considered a crime, then Payday 2 is the game for you.
